column9: Definition
column10: Example 1
column11: Example 2
column12: Example 3

column9: To exaggerate or overdo something
column10: It's tiring but I'm not going to over-egg that
column11: Don't over-egg the pudding when describing the challenges
column12: She tends to over-egg her achievements

column9: A social situation where it's easy to make mistakes or cause offense
column10: Talking about parenting is an etiquette minefield
column11: The office party was an etiquette minefield
column12: Cultural differences can create an etiquette minefield

column9: To minimize the importance or significance of something
column10: You don't want to downplay any of the good stuff
column11: She tends to downplay her achievements
column12: The company tried to downplay the incident

column9: Shared interests, beliefs, or opinions between people
column10: You find common ground with other parents
column11: We managed to find some common ground despite our differences
column12: Finding common ground is essential in negotiations

column9: To make something seem more negative or less enjoyable
column10: Don't put a downer on their joy
column11: She always puts a downer on everything
column12: I don't mean to put a downer on the celebration

column9: Extreme pessimism or negativity
column10: You don't want to be one of those doom and gloom people
column11: The economic forecast was all doom and gloom
column12: Let's have less doom and gloom and more optimism

column9: So extreme as to cause disgust or revulsion
column10: You don't want to be a nauseating parent
column11: Their public displays of affection were nauseating
column12: The smell was absolutely nauseating

column9: To avoid taking risks; to act cautiously
column10: Just play it safe when discussing sensitive topics
column11: She decided to play it safe with her investment
column12: I usually play it safe when trying new foods

column9: To make something unpleasant seem more appealing or positive
column10: It's hard to work out if people are sugarcoating things
column11: Don't sugarcoat the truth
column12: The boss tried to sugarcoat the bad news

column9: To boast or display one's abilities or achievements in a way that others find annoying
column10: You don't want to be seen as a show off
column11: He's always showing off his new car
column12: Stop showing off and let others speak

column9: To criticize or belittle oneself
column10: Putting yourself down is somehow an act of kindness
column11: Stop putting yourself down, you're doing great
column12: British people often put themselves down

column9: To present something in a more negative way than necessary
column10: In the UK we say things are just not too bad, putting a negative slant on things
column11: The media put a negative slant on the story
column12: Try not to put a negative slant on everything

column9: Tending to make oneself seem less important
column10: British people often use self-effacing humor
column11: Her self-effacing manner made everyone feel comfortable
column12: He was known for his self-effacing wit

column9: The target or victim of a joke or mockery
column10: Making yourself the butt of the joke
column11: He always ends up being the butt of the joke
column12: Don't make others the butt of your jokes

column9: To leave or disappear suddenly without explanation
column10: He ghosted out to work at summer schools
column11: She ghosted out of the party
column12: Don't ghost out on your responsibilities

column9: To expand one's experiences, knowledge, or outlook
column10: It gives them a chance to broaden their horizons
column11: Traveling helps broaden your horizons
column12: Reading can broaden your horizons

column9: Without energy or enthusiasm
column10: Students just listlessly sitting around in the park
column11: He moved listlessly through the day
column12: She listlessly picked at her food

column9: Very intense or demanding
column10: When you work at a summer school, it's quite hardcore
column11: She's a hardcore fitness enthusiast
column12: The job requires hardcore dedication

column9: In the same difficult situation as others
column10: Everyone's in the same boat so you end up making friends
column11: We're all in the same boat with this deadline
column12: Most new parents are in the same boat

column9: Having an important influence on development
column10: It's a really formative experience
column11: Those were her formative years
column12: Travel can be a formative experience

column9: To mock or make fun of someone (British slang)
column10: A lot of my friends take the piss out of me now
column11: Don't take the piss, I'm being serious
column12: They were just taking the piss

column9: To gradually become less close to someone
column10: We drifted apart after university
column11: Old friends often drift apart
column12: They slowly drifted apart over the years

column9: To contact someone, usually casually or for a favor
column10: I could hit him up on FB
column11: Hit me up when you're in town
column12: She hit up her friends for help

column9: To revive or restart something
column10: Any chance we could rekindle our friendship?
column11: They tried to rekindle their relationship
column12: He wanted to rekindle his interest in music

column9: To reveal something about yourself unintentionally
column10: I don't know if I'm giving myself away as a dinosaur
column11: Her accent gave her away
column12: His nervous laugh gave himself away
